importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the LEAP trial results were published and initial public health guidelines for early peanut introduction in infants were issued, marking a shift in medical recommendations.
The year when expanded public health guidelines for early allergen introduction were issued, leading to a significant decline in peanut allergy rates among children.
The year when updated clinical guidelines for introducing major food allergens (like peanuts) between 4 and 6 months of age were finalized and widely recommended.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This decade-long period reflects the impact of implementing early allergen introduction guidelines, with measurable reductions in peanut allergy rates observed in children from 2015 to 2025.

keyTakeAways: The early introduction of peanut products to infants—starting as early as 4 months—has led to a significant decline in peanut allergies in the U.S.
Peanut allergy rates dropped by over 27% after 2015 guidelines were issued and by over 40% after the 2017 update.
Approximately 40,000 children avoided peanut allergies since 2015, not 60,000 (corrected in article).
Early exposure to allergens like peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, soy-based yogurt, and tree nut butters is recommended as a safe and effective way to reduce allergy risk.

Despite strong scientific evidence from the LEAP trial, adoption by medical professionals remained low initially, with only 29% of pediatricians and 65% of allergists following the updated guidance by 2017.

The study by Dr. David Hill and colleagues, published in Pediatrics, analyzed electronic health records from pediatric practices and found that early allergen introduction is now being adopted and is making measurable public health impacts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A decade after the LEAP trial demonstrated that early introduction of peanuts to infants reduces the risk of developing peanut allergies, new research confirms that these recommendations have led to measurable public health benefits. Since 2015, peanut allergy rates in U.S. children under age 3 have declined by over 27% and by more than 40% after expanded guidelines in 2017. A study led by Dr. David Hill at Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia, using electronic health records, found that early allergen exposure is now being adopted and is significantly reducing allergy incidence. Approximately 40,000 children have avoided peanut allergies since 2015. Despite initial resistance and slow adoption among medical professionals, evidence shows that early feeding of allergenic foods like peanut butter, milk-based yogurt, and soy-based products is now widely recommended and supported by both medical professionals and parents. This shift reflects a major public health success in preventing a life-threatening condition.
title: Early Peanut Introduction in Infants Reduces Allergy Rates in U.S. After a Decade of Public Health Efforts
